newsitem.title: USA: US stocks shrug off bonds, Iraq to post thin gains.
newsitem.headline: US stocks shrug off bonds, Iraq to post thin gains.

text.p: U.S. blue chips ended mildly higher as investors looked past the conflict in Iraq and a soft bond market to a key economic indicator due Friday.
The Dow industrials rose nine points to close unofficially at 5657, despite session-long weakness in U.S. Treasuries ahead of Friday's payroll and unemployment report.

"The equity market is taking the view that strength in the economy implies third-quarter earnings might hold up relatively well," said Philip Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management.

Analysts said investors have adopted an especially cautious approach ahead of the jobs report, which many economists believe holds the key to whether the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates any time soon.

"At the present time both stocks and bonds are acting antsy about Friday's news," said Harry Laubscher, market analyst at Tucker Anthony. "Investors are largely on the sidelines in advance of the jobs data."
A fresh round of U.S. missile attacks on Iraqi targets early Wednesday continued to roil limited segments of the market, though oil stocks were only barely higher on the day.

The energy-hungry transportation sector remained weak, and shares in U.S. airline companies were mostly lower for the second straight session. United Airlines parent company UAL Corp fell 1/2 to 47, and American Airlines parent AMR Corp dipped two points to 80.
Retail stocks got a boost after office product retailer Staples Inc agreed to acquire competitor Office Depot Inc in a deal that would create a company with more than $10 billion in annual revenues.
Office Depot jumped 4-5/8 to 20-1/2 after the announcement, while Staples, which will pay 1.14 shares for each Office Depot share, fell 3/4 to 18-3/4.
The deal sparked strong demand for retail stocks. J.C. Penney Co Inc gained 1-7/8 to 55-1/2, May Department Stores Co gained 1-3/8 to 47-1/2 and Sears Roebuck & Co rose 1-1/8 to 44-3/4.

"You've had concern in that sector about too many competitors and margin erosion," Orlando said. "This deal suggests managements recognize the potential problem and are going to enact the strategic consolidation that is needed."

One stock that failed to participate in the retail rally was OfficeMax Inc, which slipped 5/8 to 13-1/8. The company, a direct competitor of Staples and Office Depot, said it may pursue acquisitions of its own.

Beyond the individual issues and sectors affected by special situations, stocks generally held to tight ranges in a waiting game that analysts expect will restrain the market through tomorrow's session.
Rubbermaid Inc fell 3-5/8 to 22-7/8 after warning investors that rising prices for raw materials will hurt its third-quarter earnings.

Rubbermaid said it expected Q3 profit to be little changed from the $0.32 per share it earned a year ago. That compares with analysts' estimates of about $0.40 per share. The shares touched an intraday year-low of 22-1/8 during the session.

Computer-networking company 3Com Corp rose 1-1/4 to 48-1/8 after SoundView Financial raised its short-term rating on the shares to buy from hold and increased fiscal 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates for the company.
Financial software maker Intuit Inc slid 3-3/4 to 32-1/2 after Morgan Stanley slashed its 1997 earnings estimate on the company to $0.79 per share from $1.05.
Aetna Inc jumped 2-1/8 to 67-1/8. The company said it expected pricing for its health maintenance organization plans will outpace medical cost increases.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.53 to 1143.82.
The S&P 500 index rose 0.89 to 655.61.
(Figures official as of 1645 EDT/2045 GMT)
-- Wall Street desk, 212 859-1721
